node.title: Pasifika and Asians under-represented in Environment Ministry management
node.description: Despite some gains last year, the Environment Ministry still does not resemble the diversity of wider society.

node.title: Some red regions eager to move to orange, others realistic they'll stay put
node.description: Some central North Island regions under the red traffic light are waiting with fingers crossed for a shift to orange today.

node.title: Early offers to universities are on the rise, and it's not just students who are reaping benefits
node.description: The relevance of end-of-year exams such as the HSC is in question, with new data showing a massive explosion in early offers from universities. While they were offered to help deal with disadvantage caused by lockdowns, they are so successful they will likely remain long term.

node.title: Father time: Pakistan's lonely clock collector
node.description: The tick-tock of hundreds of antique clocks fills a small hall in the south-west Pakistan city of Quetta, where collector Gul Kakar swears he will spend all the time he has left caring for them.

node.title: ‘There's a whole community out there just waiting for you’: Ella’s advice to city teens
node.description: The kindness of a regional town helped Ella breathe fresh air to her city community at a crucial time.

node.title: Travelling to Queensland from interstate? Here's what you need to know
node.description: Queensland has kept its borders shut to large chunks of Australia for many months, but that changes today, with the state opening up to travellers from domestic COVID-19 hotspots. Here are the rules around visiting.

node.title: Welcome back: Fortress Queensland ends as border thrown open to interstate arrivals
node.description: Air and road routes to Queensland are now open to all interstate travellers who are double vaccinated against COVID-19, however, border checkpoints will remain in place and border passes will still be required.

node.title: 'Serious allegations of widespread illegal activity': VicForests referred to corruption watchdog
node.description: The Victorian government-owned logging agency VicForests and its regulator have been referred to the state's anti-corruption watchdog after a string of allegations reported by the ABC since 2018.

node.title: Border exceptions announced for 600 tech workers, some agricultural workers
node.description: Hundreds of specialist tech workers and some agricultural workers will be allowed to travel to New Zealand under new border exception rules.

node.title: Vicente Fernández, iconic Mexican singer who elevated mariachi music, has died at 81
node.description: According to statements posted by his medical team on his official Instagram account, Fernández had been in and out of the intensive care unit since early August, after suffering a serious fall in his ranch and developing pneumonia.

node.title: Mikio Shinagawa, Who Ran a Fashionable SoHo Haunt, Dies at 66
node.description: His earthy Japanese restaurant, Omen, became a downtown canteen for well-known patrons like Patti Smith, Yoko Ono and Richard Gere.

node.title: Testy Exchanges Between Chris Wallace, Jake Tapper Resurface as Fox News Host Heads to CNN
node.description: After Wallace hosted a 2020 presidential debate, Tapper said he "did not have the control of the debate stage for much of the evening."

node.title: What does a year look like to you? If it's round and fuzzy, you may have time-space synaesthesia
node.description: If the past year felt like a bloated mass of time that never seemed to end, you're not alone. But some people always visualise time as a 3D form — pandemic year or not.

node.title: Sick of being treated 'like numbers and robots', these Amazon and Starbucks workers are taking on their bosses
node.description: American workers who are fed up with long shifts, non-existent breaks, and near constant surveillance at work reached "a tipping point" during the pandemic. Now they want to take on Amazon and Starbucks.

node.title: Review launched into who can call themselves a cosmetic surgeon
node.description: State and federal governments launch a landmark review aimed at overhauling laws around who can call themselves a cosmetic surgeon, after a Four Corners investigation into the industry.

node.title: The case of missing backpacker Theo Hayez and why it made a coroner cry
node.description: Where's Theo? It is a question that has been asked from Byron Bay to Belgium since the disappearance of 18-year-old backpacker Theo Hayez two and a half years ago.

node.title: Covid-19: Should Auckland move to orange?
node.description: It's decision day for Auckland, with a possibility the city moves to orange traffic light settings, as case numbers fall and vaccination rates rise. We canvassed Aucklanders to get their views.

node.title: ‘The scariest moment in my life.’ A candle factory survivor recalls the moment the tornado hit.
node.description: At Mayfield Consumer Products in Kentucky, night shift workers found themselves in the path of destruction. Many were killed.

node.title: Fox News Host Confronts Lindsey Graham Over Backing Tax Cuts That Add $2T to Deficit
node.description: Chris Wallace called out Republicans for claiming their 2017 tax cuts were paid for, saying "that was a lie."

node.title: Japanese Scientists Claim Vaccine Removes 'Zombie' Cells Behind 'Aging-Related Diseases'
node.description: "Zombie cells," officially known as senescent cells, accumulate with old age and are known to contribute to arthritis and stiffened arteries.

node.title: De Blasio Has 'Mixed Feelings' Over Allowing 800K Non-citizens to Vote in NYC Elections
node.description: A new bill passed by the New York City Council this week will allow city residents who are not U.S. citizens to vote in certain local elections.

node.title: Data deal aims to protect hospitals from cyber attacks
node.description: The Health Ministry has made a $45 million-a-year data deal to help protect hospitals from cyber attacks.

node.title: Asa Hutchinson and Bill de Blasio Spar Over Vaccine Mandates: 'It's Keeping People Alive'
node.description: Mayor de Blasio said we could leave COVID behind "if we truly focus on vaccination and put the tough mandates in place to make sure we turn the corner."

node.title: Ardern wants 'runaway increases in house price growth' to stop in 2022
node.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern says she wants to see house prices fall back from their record heights next year.

node.title: MIQ exemptions for workers as labour shortage squeezes primary sector
node.description: The government is letting more migrant workers into the country to help with the labour shortage gripping the primary sector.

node.title: Chris Wallace leaving Fox News for CNN
node.description: "After 18 years, this is my final 'Fox News Sunday,'" Wallace said.

node.title: Chris Wallace Quits Fox News for CNN After Years of Trump Attacks, Challenging GOP
node.description: "I have been free to report to the best of my ability, to cover the stories I think are important, to hold our country's leaders to account," Wallace said.

node.title: Wendy Rogers Calls New Zealand PM 'Lenin With Hair,' Claims 'Satanic Communists' in U.S.
node.description: "More bold Christians are needed in office to counter the satanic Communists in both parties," the Arizona senator tweeted on Sunday.

node.title: Commission calls for safety precautions on Te Araroa trail
node.description: The Walking Access Commission wants to see the country's longest walking trail made safer.

node.title: Transcript: Mohamed El-Erian on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Mohamed El-Erian, chief economic adviser at Allianz, that aired Sunday, December 12, 2021, on "Face the Nation."
